0.00.text:
Translator: Angelina Babinova
Reviewer: Aari Lemmik

21.30.text: The day I got laid off

22.53.text: from my job at Martha Stewart,

27.23.text: I loved the job, I really did.

30.86.text: and I didn't know how to end it

32.35.text: and then it broke up with me.

33.90.text: Don’t you love it when that happens?

35.80.text:
At the time I’ve been also 
hosting a radio show

38.26.text: for the Martha Stewart brand on Sirius XM.

40.39.text:
And then not long after 
that got cancelled, too.

44.73.text: On the day of my last show

46.08.text: I got onto the elevator at the 36th floor

48.61.text: and as it started to drop,

53.11.text:
Every floor took me further 
and further from what I had been:

57.03.text: a magazine editor, a radio host,

59.11.text:
the person with the cool job 
to talk about at parties.

64.21.text:
And honestly I had no idea 
what I was going to do.

66.60.text:
And quite frankly 
no one was looking for me.

69.37.text:
So, I did what anyone would do 
in that situation.

72.35.text: I was making some phone calls:

79.32.text:
I needed to get paid
to do something, right.

81.36.text: I mean I live in New York City.

82.52.text: If you’re not paid to do something,

83.76.text: you’re not going to be there very long.

85.98.text:
But this idea that I had to know 
what I suppose to do now, right.

89.17.text: I’m supposed to pursue this passion.

95.06.text:
And that’s because 
it’s a dangerously limiting idea

97.71.text: at the heart of everything we believe

99.66.text: about success and life in general.

102.27.text:
And it’s that you have one 
singular passion

105.13.text: and your job is to find it

107.22.text:
and to pursue it
to the exclusion of all else.

114.09.text: and if you don’t you failed.

120.32.text: and it goes your whole life,

122.20.text:
but it’s perhaps most pronounced 
when you’re graduating from school, right.

125.89.text:
After this, “Wow, the world's at your feet! 
What are you going to do now?”

131.58.text: it's like picking a major for life.

135.06.text:
You know, I had a hard enough time
picking a major for four years

137.77.text: and I changed that once, if not twice.

141.11.text:
I mean it was like just intimidating, 
right?

146.20.text: I mean this really, you know,

147.49.text:
forceful cultural imperative 
to choose your passion,

152.76.text: it’s everyone I talk to agrees with me.

155.01.text: The woman who sold me this dress.

157.06.text:
I told her what I needed the dress for,
what I was talking about

160.64.text:
I really need to hear this talk,
because I just graduate from school.

163.59.text:
My friends and I we don’t know
what we’re passionate about,

166.07.text: we don’t know what we supposed to do.”

169.47.text: I’m leery of passion for a few reasons.

171.55.text:
But one of them is 
that passion is not a plan,

179.28.text:
You can be passionate about 
a person one day, a job,

182.17.text: and then not passionate the next.

184.70.text:
We know this 
and yet we continue

186.40.text: to use passion as the yardstick

190.25.text:
instead of seeing passion 
for what it really is:

192.84.text:
the fire that ignites 
when you start rubbing sticks together.

198.27.text:
Anyway, I was such a mess
when I was in my twenties,

201.77.text:
I was anxious and depressed 
and had no life to speak of,

204.76.text: I was temping to keep my options open,

207.70.text:
and I was sitting around at night
in my underwear

211.82.text:
Actually I still do that, that’s not 
the worst thing in the world to do.

216.00.text: But I called my mother every night crying

218.11.text:
and I was turning away 
perfectly good full-time jobs.

223.56.text:
I was sure that I would pick 
the wrong one

226.01.text:
and get on the wrong train 
headed to the wrong future.

230.27.text:
My mother begged me, she said,
“Please, take a job, any job.

234.07.text:
You’re not going to be stuck, 
you’re stuck now!

238.46.text:
You don’t create your life first, 
and then live it.

240.98.text:
You create it by living it, 
not agonizing about it.”

246.63.text:
And so I took a full-time job 
as an assistant

249.64.text:
at a management consulting firm, 
where I knew nothing about nothing.

255.21.text:
Except I knew I had a reason to get up 
in the morning, get showered,

259.36.text:
people who were waiting 
for me when I got there

261.68.text: and I got a paycheck every two weeks.

263.58.text:
And that is as good a reason 
to take a job as any.

267.36.text:
Did I know that I want to be 
an office administrator

270.01.text:
for the rest of my life?
No! I had no idea!

274.22.text:
But this idea that 
everything you're supposed to do

276.62.text:
should fit into this passion vertical 
is unrealistic.

282.51.text:
You show me someone 
who washes windows for a living

284.97.text: and I will bet you a million dollars

286.96.text:
it’s not because 
he has a passion for clean glass.

292.66.text:
One of my favourite columns is a piece 
by Dilbert creator Scott Adams.

296.32.text:
He wrote a piece in The Wall Street Journal
a few years ago,

298.62.text: about how we failed his way to success.

300.53.text:
And one of his jobs was 
a commercial loan officer.

306.45.text:
"Do not loan money 
to someone following their passion."

313.27.text:
No, loan it to someone 
who wants to start a business,

320.24.text:
Adam says that in his life 
success fueled passion

327.68.text:
When I got my first job 
as a magazine editor, in publishing,

331.69.text: But I had to take pretty big pay cut,

333.96.text:
because at the time I’d been 
a catalogue copywriter at a wig company.

340.20.text:
Laugh if you will, clearly you are 
and many, many people did.

345.51.text:
So I had to figure out a way
to make some money.

347.35.text:
A friend of mine invited me
to a jewelry party

349.59.text: I said, "What is a jewelry party?"

351.34.text:
She said, “It’s like Tupperware
but with bracelets.”

353.02.text: I said, “Okay, got it, got it.”

355.27.text: I went and I had the best time.

357.60.text:
I was there hanging out, 
trying on jewelry,

359.71.text: the salespersons having a great time

361.12.text: and I was like, "That’s a job.

366.95.text:
I mean, really, she seems
to be having a great time.

369.33.text: Now, I had no background in sales,

371.20.text:
unless you count Girl Scouts,
and I was terrible.

373.62.text: And I had no passion for jewelry.

375.71.text:
I mean, honestly, my earrings 
cost 20 $. Combined, all of them.

380.82.text:
And yet I was like, "I think I can sling 
silver jewelry to suburban moms

388.46.text:
And so I did it, I signed up, 
I became a Silpada Designs rep.

392.37.text:
Listen to me, I was not
setting a world on fire right away.

394.83.text:
Really.
I was so awkward and afraid of selling.

401.60.text:
I started getting
really passionate about it.

403.60.text:
Not just because of the money,
but because

405.14.text:
what I realized was
people wanted the stuff.

407.13.text: They were happy to pay for it.

409.47.text:
I sold so much jewelry that year 
I won a free trip to Saint Thomas.

414.98.text:
I eventually let my jewelry business go,
because my career path shifted.

418.77.text: But I was so glad that I did that.

421.02.text:
Because it planted an entrepreneurial 
seed I didn’t know was there.

424.62.text: And that bears fruit to this day.

428.07.text:
Now as you know an entire 
cottage industry has sprung up

430.78.text:
around helping people
find their passions, right.

434.85.text:
And their hearts in the right place,
it’s great, I’m all about self-discovery.

439.35.text:
But when you ask someone, 
or you’re asked like,

444.75.text:
It’s like, "Oh my god, I have to 
came out with a good answer for this."

448.19.text:
One of my friends in her mid-forties
and she’s looking

450.92.text: what’s her life going to be now.

452.45.text:
And she’s like, 
“I don’t know what I’m passionate about.”

456.10.text:
And she’s legitimately 
concerned about this.

458.22.text: She’s ready to hire a team of people.

460.00.text:
It’s like,
why are we worrying about this?

461.70.text:
You know why, because she thinks 
something wrong with her.

463.50.text:
I thought something was wrong with me 
when I was in the seventh grade

466.53.text: and everyone was really into like

470.51.text:
and they would carve the names 
of those bands in a tables in a library.

474.12.text:
And I never carved anything, because 
I couldn’t think of anything to carve.

479.63.text:
I mean I liked Bon Jovi 
as much as the next girl,

482.45.text:
but not enough to deface 
school propriety, you know.

486.54.text:
It’s probably why 
I don’t have any tattoos either.

491.28.text:
I was really boring, 
I thought something was wrong with me.

495.09.text: But that’s the fear, isn’t it?

497.26.text:
That when someone asks you 
at a party, on a date, at a job interview,

505.04.text:
That you're not going to have 
this wow compelling answer.

508.21.text:
And that means that you’re 
not interesting, or ambitious,

512.15.text:
or that you don’t have 
a singular obsession

514.47.text: or scary talent that you hiding.

516.29.text: And that your life isn’t worth living.

520.67.text: Passion is not a job, a sport, or a hobby.

524.67.text: It is the full force of your attention

527.36.text:
and energy that you give to
whatever is right in front of you.

530.26.text:
And if you’re so busy looking for this 
passion,

533.80.text:
you could miss opportunities 
that change your life.

538.25.text: You could also miss out on a great love.

540.92.text:
Because that’s what happens
when you have tunnel vision,

547.16.text:
We all think we know 
the kind of person we are

549.55.text: and the kind of person we could love.

556.11.text:
And sometimes you don’t know
what you're going to do next, right?

560.63.text:
I love not knowing what I’m going
to be doing five years from now

564.45.text: And that’s okay, it’s okay not to know.

571.07.text:
are those that still have the power 
to surprise you.

576.06.text:
And as for the things you know 
you want to do.

578.31.text:
You want to write a book,
you want to start a business,

583.18.text:
But if you’re sitting around waiting
for passion to show up and take it,

585.89.text: you’re going to be waiting a long time.

590.53.text: Instead, spend your time and attention

596.92.text: Look for problems that need solving.

602.66.text:
People will thank you, and hug you 
and pay you for it

607.45.text:
Where your energy and effort 
meets someone else’s need.

614.38.text: and realizing what you have to contribute.

617.28.text:
Why do you think when we’re asking people
what they’re passionate about,

629.09.text:
Because to live a life 
full of meaning and value

633.59.text:
you don’t follow you passion, 
your passion follows you.
